Elsevier and other academic publishers have pivoted from oligopolistic publishers to researcher-surveillance vendors. They track everything you do and sell the analysis back to your employers.

It's about time that academics became more aware of this.

a great point Kate Crawford made in her interview on Chris Hayes’ podcast is that AI is essentially an **extractive** industry that 1) “mines” content from the internet for its models, 2) depends on cheap labor in developing countries, and 3) uses a **huge** amount of natural resources in the sense that it takes a lot of computing power and therefore energy to train the models and poop out its amusing little answers. https://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/amp/ncna1304427

For the first time ever, https://the-federation.info reports that Mastodon is now a minority of nodes on the Fediverse.

23,578 Fediverse nodes are counted, with 9,851 nodes being Mastodon servers.

Unlike other stats sites, https://the-federation.info counts servers that don't use ActivityPub -- such as Matrix, Diaspora, and Bluesky.

This is exciting: the more decentralization, the better!

@fediversenews

title: Six Centuries of Type & Printing (letterpress and ebook bundle)

last_post.content: Back in 2020, I published Six Centuries of Type & Printing, a concise book – 64 pages – that actually starts centuries before Gutenberg, with Chinese and Korea printing, and then digs into 1450 to 2020, covering ~600 years of technological advances. Set in hot-metal type (Monotype Bembo) in North Yorkshire, printed in London, and bound in Germany with a foil-stamped cover & slipcase, I still have copies available for shipping worldwide! https://glog.glennf.com/tiny-type-museum-time-capsule-and-more/six-centuries-letterpress (ebook edition available)

title: Computer Shopper February 1986 : Computer Shopper : Free Download, Borrow, and Streaming : Internet Archive

last_post.content:
I'm happy to announce the first of the Computer Shoppers has been scanned.

https://archive.org/details/computer-shopper-february-1986

This includes an Aesthetic and Readable version (aimed towards looking like the bleedthrough newsprint original, as well as one for better reading). Thanks to Gaming Alexandria for post-processing. The 70gb RAW scans will also be made available.

Tons of points were learned doing this, so expect the next ones to rock harder. Thanks, everyone who contributed to this project.

title: Research Paper | Developer Thriving: The four factors that drive Software Developer Productivity across Industries

last_post.content:
@grimalkina et al. refer to "bottom-up" visibility: "communicating engineering effort to organizations". Frequent commits, open PRs, etc. create transparency, but this data must be "translated" to the rest of the organization. https://www.pluralsight.com/resource-center/guides/developer-thriving-research-paper

The New Yorker piece talks about not mistaking transparency as a first-order good: really, what I care about is *trust*. On cross-functional teams, transparency needs to be joined with translation to achieve trust. Transparency alone is not enough.
Dark Matter Developers: The Unseen 99% (2012) - https://www.hanselman.com/blog/dark-matter-developers-the-unseen-99

title: Blockchain and Trust - Schneier on Security

last_post.content:
@graue @pluralistic Bruce Schneier wrote a great article about this in 2019:

https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2019/02/blockchain_and_.html

Cryptocurrencies don't remove the requirement for trust - it just moves the trust around a bit.

title: NASA’s Webb Scores Another Ringed World With New Image of Uranus

last_post.content:
This zoomed-in image of #Uranus, captured by #JWST’s Near-Infrared Camera (NIRCam) Feb. 6, 2023, reveals stunning views of the #planet’s rings.

The planet displays a blue hue in this representative-color image, made by combining data from two filters at 1.4 and 3.0 microns, which are shown here as blue and orange, respectively.

#astronomy #astrophotography

title: GitHub - socialweb-php/atproto: A PHP library for integrating with and communicating over the AT Protocol

last_post.content:
I decided to play around with the AT Protocol, so I put together a very rough & very early #PHP library to play around with the concepts.

If you're interested, check it out, & I'd love to have others contribute to round it out and make it full-featured.

Ultimately, I’d love this library to be a starting point for working on some #ActivityPub / #ATProtocol bridging.

title: Getting What You Measure: Four common pitfalls in using software metrics for project management: Queue: Vol 10, No 5

last_post.content:
I also quite like how the Pluralsight developer productivity study built on our "Getting What You Measure" paper, rephrasing our common metric pitfalls as:

1. We tend to measure things without enough context.
2. We're concerned about the appearance, but not really the meaning of what we've measured.
3. We have not measured enough things.
4. We measure many things, but they do not feel related to each other.

https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/2208917.2229115

https://www.pluralsight.com/resource-center/guides/developer-thriving-research-paper

#DeveloperProductivity #Pluralsight

ActivityPub can support portable identities, using the infrastructure and protocol that we already have: https://shadowfacts.net/2023/activitypub-portable-identity/

The crux of the issue with current software like Mastodon is that people and posts are identified by where they’re hosted, not who they belong to. It’s as if the URL for my blog post was https://5.161.136.163/2023/activitypub-portable-identity/. It moves the post from being controlled by me, the owner of shadowfacts.net, to my hosting provider who controls that IP address. But the web doesn’t work like that, and nor does ActivityPub have to.

ActivityPub can support portable identities, using the infrastructure and protocol that we already have: https://shadowfacts.net/2023/activitypub-portable-identity/
